verses.text: And the \sc Lord\sc* spake unto Moses and Aaron, saying,

When a man shall have in the skin of his flesh a rising, a scab, or bright spot, and it be in the skin of his flesh like the plague of leprosy; then he shall be brought unto Aaron the priest, or unto one of his sons the priests:

and the priest shall look on the plague in the skin of the flesh: and \add when\add* the hair in the plague is turned white, and the plague in sight \add be\add* deeper than the skin of his flesh, it \add is\add* a plague of leprosy: and the priest shall look on him, and pronounce him unclean.

If the bright spot \add be\add* white in the skin of his flesh, and in sight \add be\add* not deeper than the skin, and the hair thereof be not turned white; then the priest shall shut up \add him that hath\add* the plague seven days:

and the priest shall look on him the seventh day: and behold, \add if\add* the plague in his sight be at a stay, \add and\add* the plague spread not in the skin; then the priest shall shut him up seven days more:

and the priest shall look on him again the seventh day: and behold, \add if\add* the plague \add be\add* somewhat dark, and the plague spread not in the skin, the priest shall pronounce him clean: it \add is but\add* a scab: and he shall wash his clothes, and be clean.
But if the scab spread much abroad in the skin, after that he hath been seen of the priest for his cleansing, he shall be seen of the priest again:
and \add if\add* the priest see that behold, the scab spreadeth in the skin, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean: it \add is\add* a leprosy.
When the plague of leprosy is in a man, then he shall be brought unto the priest;
and the priest shall see \add him:\add* and behold, \add if\add* the rising \add be\add* white in the skin, and it have turned the hair white, and \add there be\add* quick raw flesh in the rising;
it \add is\add* an old leprosy in the skin of his flesh, and the priest shall pronounce him unclean, \add and\add* shall not shut him up: for he \add is\add* unclean.
And if a leprosy break out abroad in the skin, and the leprosy cover all the skin of \add him that hath\add* the plague from his head even to his foot, wheresoever the priest looketh;

then the priest shall consider: and behold, \add if\add* the leprosy have covered all his flesh, he shall pronounce \add him\add* clean \add that hath\add* the plague: it is all turned white: he \add is\add* clean.
But when raw flesh appeareth in him, he shall be unclean.
And the priest shall see the raw flesh, and pronounce him to be unclean: \add for\add* the raw flesh \add is\add* unclean: it \add is\add* a leprosy.
Or if the raw flesh turn again, and be changed unto white, he shall come unto the priest;
and the priest shall see him: and behold, \add if\add* the plague be turned into white; then the priest shall pronounce \add him\add* clean \add that hath\add* the plague: he \add is\add* clean.
The flesh also, in which, \add even\add* in the skin thereof, was a boil, and is healed,
and in the place of the boil there be a white rising, or a bright spot, white, \add and\add* somewhat reddish, and it be shewed to the priest;

and if, when the priest seeth it, behold, it \add be\add* in sight lower than the skin, and the hair thereof be turned white; the priest shall pronounce him unclean: it \add is\add* a plague of leprosy broken out of the boil.

But if the priest look on it, and behold, \add there be\add* no white hairs therein, and \add if\add* it \add be\add* not lower than the skin, but \add be\add* somewhat dark; then the priest shall shut him up seven days:
and if it spread much abroad in the skin, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean: it \add is\add* a plague.
But if the bright spot stay in his place, \add and\add* spread not, it \add is\add* a burning boil; and the priest shall pronounce him clean.
Or if there be \add any\add* flesh, in the skin whereof \add there is\add* a hot burning, and the quick \add flesh\add* that burneth have a white bright spot, somewhat reddish, or white;

then the priest shall look upon it: and behold, \add if\add* the hair in the bright spot be turned white, and it \add be\add* in sight deeper than the skin; it \add is\add* a leprosy broken out of the burning: wherefore the priest shall pronounce him unclean: it \add is\add* the plague of leprosy.

But if the priest look on it, and behold, \add there be\add* no white hair in the bright spot, and it \add be\add* no lower than the \add other\add* skin, but \add be\add* somewhat dark; then the priest shall shut him up seven days:
and the priest shall look upon him the seventh day: \add and\add* if it be spread much abroad in the skin, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean: it \add is\add* the plague of leprosy.

And if the bright spot stay in his place, \add and\add* spread not in the skin, but it \add be\add* somewhat dark; it \add is\add* a rising of the burning, and the priest shall pronounce him clean: for it \add is\add* an inflammation of the burning.
If a man or woman hath a plague upon the head or the beard;

then the priest shall see the plague: and behold, \add if\add* it \add be\add* in sight deeper than the skin; and \add there be\add* in it a yellow thin hair; then the priest shall pronounce him unclean: it \add is\add* a dry scall, \add even\add* a leprosy upon the head or beard.

And if the priest look on the plague of the scall, and behold, it \add be\add* not in sight deeper than the skin, and \add that there is\add* no black hair in it; then the priest shall shut up \add him that hath\add* the plague of the scall seven days:

and in the seventh day the priest shall look on the plague: and behold, \add if\add* the scall spread not, and there be in it no yellow hair, and the scall \add be\add* not in sight deeper than the skin;
he shall be shaven, but the scall shall he not shave; and the priest shall shut up \add him that hath\add* the scall seven days more:

and in the seventh day the priest shall look on the scall: and behold, \add if\add* the scall be not spread in the skin, nor \add be\add* in sight deeper than the skin; then the priest shall pronounce him clean: and he shall wash his clothes, and be clean.
But if the scall spread much in the skin after his cleansing;
then the priest shall look on him: and behold, \add if\add* the scall be spread in the skin, the priest shall not seek for yellow hair: he \add is\add* unclean.
But if the scall be in his sight at a stay, and \add that\add* there is black hair grown up therein; the scall is healed, he \add is\add* clean: and the priest shall pronounce him clean.
If a man also or a woman have in the skin of their flesh bright spots, \add even\add* white bright spots;

then the priest shall look: and behold, \add if\add* the bright spots in the skin of their flesh \add be\add* darkish white; it \add is\add* a freckled spot \add that\add* groweth in the skin: he \add is\add* clean.
And the man whose hair is fallen off his head, he \add is\add* bald: \add yet is\add* he clean.
And he that hath his hair fallen off from the part of \add his head toward\add* his face, he \add is\add* forehead bald: \add yet is\add* he clean.
And if there be in the bald head, or bald forehead, a white reddish sore; it \add is\add* a leprosy sprung up in his bald head, or his bald forehead.

Then the priest shall look upon it: and behold, \add if\add* the rising of the sore \add be\add* white reddish in his bald head, or in his bald forehead, as the leprosy appeareth in the skin of the flesh;
he \add is\add* a leprous man, he \add is\add* unclean: the priest shall pronounce him utterly unclean, his plague \add is\add* in his head.
And the leper in whom the plague \add is\add*, his clothes shall be rent, and his head bare, and he shall put a covering upon \add his\add* upper lip, and shall cry, Unclean, unclean.
All the days wherein the plague \add shall be\add* in him he shall be defiled; he \add is\add* unclean: he shall dwell alone; without the camp \add shall\add* his habitation \add be\add*.
The garment also that the plague of leprosy is in, \add whether it be\add* a woollen garment, or a linen garment;
whether \add it be\add* in the warp, or woof; of linen, or of woollen; whether in a skin, or in any thing made of skin;

and \add if\add* the plague be greenish or reddish in the garment, or in the skin, either in the warp, or in the woof, or in any thing of skin; it \add is\add* a plague of leprosy, and shall be shewed unto the priest:
and the priest shall look upon the plague, and shut up \add it that hath\add* the plague seven days:

and he shall look on the plague on the seventh day: if the plague be spread in the garment, either in the warp, or in the woof, or in a skin, \add or\add* in any work that is made of skin; the plague \add is\add* a fretting leprosy; it \add is\add* unclean.

He shall therefore burn \add that\add* garment, whether warp or woof, in woollen or in linen, or any thing of skin, wherein the plague is: for it \add is\add* a fretting leprosy; it shall be burnt in the fire.
And if the priest shall look, and behold, the plague be not spread in the garment, either in the warp, or in the woof, or in any thing of skin;
then the priest shall command that they wash \add the thing\add* wherein the plague \add is\add*, and he shall shut it up seven days more:

and the priest shall look on the plague, after \add that\add* it is washed: and behold, \add if\add* the plague have not changed his colour, and the plague be not spread; it \add is\add* unclean; thou shalt burn it in the fire; it \add is\add* fret inward, \add whether\add* it \add be\add* bare within or without.

And if the priest look, and behold, the plague \add be\add* somewhat dark after the washing of it; then he shall rend it out of the garment, or out of the skin, or out of the warp, or out of the woof:

and if it appear still in the garment, either in the warp, or in the woof, or in any thing of skin; it \add is\add* a spreading \add plague:\add* thou shalt burn that wherein the plague \add is\add* with fire.

And the garment, either warp, or woof, or whatsoever thing of skin \add it be\add*, which thou shalt wash, if the plague be departed from them, then it shall be washed the second time, and shall be clean.
This \add is\add* the law of the plague of leprosy in a garment of woollen or linen, either \add in\add* the warp, or woof, or any thing of skins, to pronounce it clean, or to pronounce it unclean.
